name: Onion Dosa
history: Onion Dosa is a variation of the classic South Indian dosa. It incorporates onions, adding a delicious crunch and sweetness to the traditional crepe-like dish.
description: Onion Dosa is a savory crepe made from a fermented batter of rice and lentils, topped with finely chopped onions and spices. It's a popular breakfast or snack item in South Indian cuisine.

equipment.name: spatula
equipment.description: For spreading and flipping the dosas.

instructions.title: Prepare Dosa Batter
instructions.description: Soak the parboiled rice, urad dal, and fenugreek seeds in water for at least 6 hours or overnight. Drain and grind them into a smooth batter, adding water as needed. The consistency of the batter should be thick yet pourable. Transfer the batter to a large mixing bowl, cover, and let it ferment in a warm place for 8-10 hours or until it doubles in size.

instructions.title: Prepare Onion Topping
instructions.description: In a small bowl, mix the finely chopped onions, green chilies, cumin seeds, and chopped coriander leaves. Set aside.

instructions.title: Make the Dosas
instructions.description: Heat a griddle or tawa over medium heat. Pour a ladleful of the fermented dosa batter onto the center of the griddle. Using the back of the ladle, spread the batter in a circular motion to form a thin crepe.

instructions.title: Add Onion Topping
instructions.description: Sprinkle the onion topping mixture evenly over the dosa. Drizzle a little oil around the edges. Cook until the dosa turns golden brown and crisp at the bottom.

instructions.title: Serve the Dosa
instructions.description: Fold the dosa and serve hot with chutney or sambar. Repeat with the remaining batter and onion topping.

tips: Make sure the griddle is well-heated before pouring the batter for the best results.
Fermentation time for the batter may vary depending on the climate. Warmer climates facilitate faster fermentation.
variations: Add grated carrots or beetroot to the onion topping for additional nutrition and color.
Experiment with different types of chutneys like coconut, tomato, or peanut for variety.

storage.shelfLife: Dosa batter can be refrigerated for up to 2 days.
storage.instructions: Store the batter in an airtight container in the refrigerator. Stir well before using.

reheatingInstructions.instruction: Reheat the dosa on a hot griddle or tawa for a few minutes until warm and crispy.

presentationTips: Serve on a banana leaf or a clean plate with the chutney and sambar on the side.
Garnish with a wedge of lime and a sprinkle of fresh coriander.
